p: Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA, 18:3, n-3), eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA, 20:5, n-3), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA, 22:6, n-3) are the prominent representatives of the omega-3 family ( Figure 1). ALA is a precursor of the omega-3 family ( Figure 2) and also the only omega-3 that must be derived from the diet, since it cannot be produced by the human body. Regarding food sources, it is found in vegetable oils such as flaxseed (linseed), canola (rapeseed), soybean, and hemp oil, nuts, such as walnuts, as well as in seeds (e.g., chia ( Salvia hispanica)), dairy products, eggs, and algae [ 14, 15, 16, 17]. Omega-3 fatty acids can also be found in the meat of free-ranged animals (herbivores and carnivores).
